Summers is the Charles W. Eliot University Professor at Harvard University's
Kennedy School of Government. He is the 1993 recipient of the John Bates Clark
Medal for his work in several fields of economics.

Summers also served as the 27th President of Harvard University from 2001 to
2006. Summers resigned as Harvard's president in the wake of a no-confidence
vote by Harvard faculty that resulted in large part from Summers's conflict with
Cornel West, financial conflict of interest questions regarding his relationship
with Andrei Shleifer, and a 2005 speech in which he suggested that the under-
representation of women in science and engineering could be due to a "different
availability of aptitude at the high end," and less to patterns of
discrimination and socialization.

Summers has also been criticized for the economic policies he advocated as
Treasury Secretary and in later writings. [http://money.cnn.com/2008/11/23/-
news/economy/obama_summers/index.htm Obama picks Summers as top economic
adviser]. CNN Money. November 23, 2008. In 2009, he was tapped by
President Obama to be the director of the White House National Economic
Council. {{cite news
